subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New member- and help with Macs?
msgSnippet:

only apps I have which displays Quikscript flawlessly (i.e. mapping the

messageBody:
That's kind of funny, firefox (GTK+ version) and gnome-terminal are the
only apps I have which displays Quikscript flawlessly (i.e. mapping the
glyphs without any hints), I've got a screen shot up at
http://uk.geocities.com/amd64_hacker/Screenshot.png.
Everything else needs the kind of hand holding you describe for Safari,
specifying a font name (which means you have to hope the correct font is
installed).

In my case (and I'd suspect you're having the same problem) it's because
there is no script code for Quikscript so the computer treats them as
whatever glyph is E6xx in the current font (usually nothing).
Firefox and gnome-terminal work for me because they do their own font
handling and probably don't pay attention to scripts (actually
gnome-terminal's font handling is broken but no ones 'fixed' it yet).
When we have a script code the computer will (if it's sensibly
programmed) only consider fonts with our script code for quikscript.

Incidentally I've nominated it before - but I think Quik would be good
as our code.

Oh and thanks for Kingsley.ttf (I've already installed it as you can see
:), it is so easy on the eyes.
I think the next step would be to setup gsub/gpos tables so we can do
cursive writing.
Tim and Paige have ideas about this also, perhaps we can get together on
YIM to discuss it in real time?

oliver langan wrote:
>
> On 19 Jul 2006, at 11:18, meosongrey wrote:
> > I have close to zero programming experience, so I don't really know
> > how to make the
> > fonts appear in either Safari or Internet Explorer. I tried
> > changing the font Preferences
> > in Safari to one the Kingsley, and ended up with all of my
> > Microsoft Outlook inbox
> > written in that font--but nothing that was supposed to be written
> > in that font
> > appearing correct.
> >
> > How should I go about mixing both Roman for where Roman is written
> > on the internet
> > with one of the Shavian/Quikscript fonts? As an aside, when I tried
> > to download the
> > one through Yahoo, it never got past the "initiating download
> > stage", though I will try
> > again later today.
>
> I have had success in getting the Unicode font to display in Safari,
> but only if the HTML file specifically indicates that it is to be
> used. After installing the Kingsley.ttf file that I recently
> uploaded, you can try this test page:
> http://slate.langan.net/QS_unicode_sample.html
> <http://slate.langan.net/QS_unicode_sample.html>
> It is simply the HTML-marked-up version of the text file which I
> posted to the files section.
>
> However, that file does NOT display properly in Firefox, at least not
> for me. All my fonts are screwed up (slightly) in Firefox, perhaps
> because I am using the Cross-Platform Portable version.
>
> oliver
>
>

That's kind of funny, firefox (GTK+ version) and gnome-terminal are the
only apps I have which displays Quikscript flawlessly (i.e. mapping the
glyphs without any hints), I've got a screen shot up at
http://uk.geocities.com/amd64_hacker/Screenshot.png.
Everything else needs the kind of hand holding you describe for Safari,
specifying a font name (which means you have to hope the correct font is
installed).

In my case (and I'd suspect you're having the same problem) it's because
there is no script code for Quikscript so the computer treats them as
whatever glyph is E6xx  in the current font (usually nothing).
Firefox and gnome-terminal work for me because they do their own font
handling and probably don't pay attention to scripts (actually
gnome-terminal's font handling is broken but no ones 'fixed' it yet).
When we have a script code the computer will (if it's sensibly
programmed) only consider fonts with our script code for quikscript.

Incidentally I've nominated it before - but I think Quik would be good
as our code.

Oh and thanks for Kingsley.ttf (I've already installed it as you can see
:), it is so easy on the eyes.
I think the next step would be to setup gsub/gpos tables so we can do
cursive writing.
Tim and Paige have ideas about this also, perhaps we can get together on
YIM to discuss it in real time?
